file_content.text: We need you back at headquarters immediately. Orders from above.
Above Darth Jadus?
Whose orders?
Not precisely, sir. I need to go.
Above the Minister of Intelligence?
Whose orders?
Sith orders, sir. I need to go.
On my way.
Acknowledged. Watcher Three out.
What disaster is in store this time?
More bad news, I assume.
I'm sorry, I can't give more details. Watcher Three out.
We've never seen him act like that.
I'm sure he's merely distracted. Shall we head home?
This is Cipher Nine to headquarters. Stand by for a full report and data upload.
Receiving data, Cipher Nine. I'll send it for processing right away, but you'll have to save the report.
You should get to Voss, sir. I'll do what I can.
Sir? Keeper and the others are in the conference room. They're waiting for you.
This is Watcher Three. Retrieving the holorecording from the Tytun Rings takes priority now, Cipher; report back later.
Apologies for the interruption, but we have a new lead.
Watchers Six, Seven and Nine have been searching HoloNet records for conspirator activity. Three billion lines of communication routing sequences and credit transfer verifications.
They've found traces of a holoconference held six months ago between Hunter and parties unknown.
Could he have been reporting to his superiors?
A meeting of conspirators.
That is my hope.
Three billion lines is a lot to sort through.
How did they find it?
They see the patterns better than I do.
We need proof, not computer logs.
Finding "traces" doesn't help.
And if this is Hunter reporting home? What does that mean to you?
Unfortunately, this is only a record of the call--not the call itself. Even the Empire can't store every bit of data that crosses the HoloNet.
A HoloNet archive does exist, however: the Tytun Rings, a massive, self-maintaining repository of all galactic communications.
What are the "Tytun Rings" exactly?
I've never heard of it.
The storage, the technology, the expense of something like that....
How is that possible?
By your tone, I'm guessing visitors are discouraged.
My next target, I assume?
About a century ago, an entrepreneur cyberformed the Tytun Four moon into an enormous databank designed to listen and record.
It was operated by droids and protected by mercenary contract. Like all archives, it ran out of space.
Thus, the Tytun Rings--a fleet of wrecked starships salvaged for the purpose of data storage. They orbit the moon, still recording, still protected by the mercenaries.
Setting course for the Tytun Rings now.
On my way.
You said the archive was founded by an entrepreneur. Who's behind it? What's the purpose?
Tell me about the operation.
No one knows. Most stories credit a Hutt richer than sin or an Alderaanian noble who bankrupted himself setting it up.
According to the mercenary contract, the information is to be preserved for "historical use" in a few centuries' time.
In other words, no one gets their hands on it.
This can't be the first time someone realized the archive's value.
Has anyone tried before?
No, but negotiations aren't well received, and a full assault could damage the databanks. Cipher Eight died escaping our last infiltration.
What's the opposition like?
Details on the mercenaries?
Trandoshans, mostly, better trained and equipped than the usual.
I'm sure I can surprise our mercenary friends.
Until me.
Promise me it's for the good of the Empire, and I'll steal whatever data you like.
Time to play burglar.
You are reliable that way.
The conspirators' recording is located in archive node 803-A--a derelict Imperial transport ruined in the Battle of Druckenwell.
Watchers Six, Seven and Nine will guide you once you're aboard. I want that conference recording, Cipher--Keeper out.
Cipher--station security reported what happened.
The conspirators know who you are. They must have your full record... and they're recruiting your enemies.
If my identity goes public, I'll be hunted through half the galaxy.
That could be a problem.
I know. I'll--hold on. Transferring you to Keeper.
They want to make my life difficult, I can't stop them. We need to stay on task.
Nothing we can do now.
People I've already beaten are the least of my worries.
My old enemies are pushovers.
Maybe. We'll try to run damage control, but--hold on. Transferring you to Keeper.
